title: Why were slave owners so inhumane towards their slaves? - Quora
tags: History of the United States of America

response.answer_text: This question assumes that the owners of slaves were by definition inhumane. While the entire system was by its very form inhumane, over slavery times there were millions of slaves and tens of thousands of owners. Slaves were valuable property. A wise owner would house and feed slaves so as to get the maximum profit from them, just like a farmer would treat his (or her—women owned slaves, too) horses and other livestock. That’s perhaps where the inhumanity lurks, in treating people as if they were livestock. Owners ran the whole range of human characters. There were sadistic owners who abused and murdered slaves. Slave women were sexually exploited, although on how large a scale is not known. Some owners are known to have been kindly, and a more a few freed their slaves, sometimes out of conscience aroused by religious conversion. White children would play with black children and might well have a black nanny, and these relationships could endure into adulthood. And it was not rare that slaves and white families were kin. The grosser forms of inhumanity could occur at times of bankruptcy or the death of the legal owners. Slaves might be sold to settle debts, or slave families broken up with each of the heirs getting some human loot as inheritance. Slave marriages were not legally recognized, and children could quite legally be sold away from their families. Traditions eased the inhumanity somewhat. In most areas slaves were allowed religion, and often a half day on Sunday for rest of gardening. In some places the span between Christmas and New Year’s was granted as a kind of vacation. It’s also worth noting that there were some African Americans who owned slaves, free people, largely mixed-race, in Louisiana. There were also slaves owned by Indians, particularly in the Indian territory (now Oklahoma). And then there was the lash. Slave resistance of any sort was apt to be punished harshly, by whipping or beating, and even physical mutilation. Owners sometimes rented their slaves out or hired overseers to manage their slaves—think of a family living gracefully in Charleston who hired an overseer to manage their plantation. But sometimes resistance paid off—read the autobiography of the remarkable Frederick Douglass, who recalls a knock down, drag out fight with a white overseer.
